FAQs.question: What is Chlamydia?
FAQs.answer: Chlamydia is a common sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis.

FAQs.question: How is Chlamydia transmitted?
FAQs.answer: Chlamydia is spread through vaginal, anal, or oral sex with an infected person.

FAQs.question: What are the symptoms of Chlamydia?
FAQs.answer: Symptoms may include abnormal discharge, painful urination, or no symptoms at all.

FAQs.question: Can Chlamydia be cured?
FAQs.answer: Yes, Chlamydia can be cured with antibiotics.

FAQs.question: What happens if Chlamydia is left untreated?
FAQs.answer: Untreated Chlamydia can lead to serious health issues like pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) and infertility.

FAQs.question: Can Chlamydia be asymptomatic?
FAQs.answer: Yes, many people with Chlamydia show no symptoms.

FAQs.question: How can I prevent Chlamydia?
FAQs.answer: Using condoms during sex and getting regular STI screenings can help prevent Chlamydia.

FAQs.question: Can Chlamydia affect pregnancy?
FAQs.answer: Yes, Chlamydia during pregnancy can lead to complications like premature birth and transmission to the baby.

FAQs.question: Can I get Chlamydia more than once?
FAQs.answer: Yes, you can be reinfected with Chlamydia even after treatment if exposed again.

FAQs.question: How is Chlamydia diagnosed?
FAQs.answer: Chlamydia is diagnosed through a urine test or a swab of the infected area.
